Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Expanding the Toolbox of Encodable Fluorescent Probes to Image Macrophage Redox Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division, Dr. Huiwang Ai and his research team at the University of California, Riverside are developing new methods for the detection of hydrogen sulfide and other redox-active molecules in living cells. Fluorescent proteins in nonnative topologies with nonnatural chromophore structures will be exploited as novel redox probes. These selective fluorescent probes will be utilized to uncover the mechanisms of redox response and regulation in macrophage immune cells. The project will result in a general strategy for probing redox-active small signaling molecules in subcellular locations and in space close to proteins of interest.

It is widely accepted by the scientific community that cells use redox-active molecules to generate and relay signals. The misregulation of these processes is linked to a large number of diseases. Dr. Ai and his coworkers have discovered the means to selectively observe redox-active molecules in live cells. This project will be a necessary step toward a more comprehensive understanding of redox signaling and regulation. The project will also train graduate and undergraduate students for specialized expertise at the chemistry-biology interface. Middle and high school students from the local STEM school will be supported for research experiences. Curriculum enhancements and outreach activities will be carried out to further broaden the impacts of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is widely accepted that cells need to maintain reduction-oxidation (redox) homeostasis for proper functions. Redox chemical reactions have been identified for broad uses in and between cells to generate and relay signals. Research in this field was greatly hindered by the lack of available methods to detect hydrogen sulfide and other redox-active molecules in living cells.

The main outcomes of this NSF-funded project are the development of genetically encoded fluorescent probes for redox signaling and oxidative stress, and the expansion of a novel biosensor development strategy based on unnatural-amino-acid-modified fluorescent proteins.

A genetic code expansion technology has been utilized to introduce unnatural amino acids into fluorescent proteins in nonnative topologies, leading to the development of selective fluorescent probes for hydrogen peroxide and several redox-active molecules. To further enhance the performance of the first-generation biosensors, the team performed directed evolution and derived much improved probes, which were used to detect biologically generated hydrogen sulfide and peroxynitrite. To extend this strategy for ratiometric measurement which eliminates many detection uncertainties via self-calibration at two wavelengths, the team genetically fused the biosensors with a blue fluorescent protein for resonance energy transfer, resulting in ratiometric, genetically encoded fluorescent biosensors.

The team further explored the molecular mechanism for the unexpected chemoselectivity of the highly selective peroxynitrite sensor. It was discovered that a histidine residue on the protein scaffold polarized a water molecule to induce a different hybridization state of the boron atom in the chromophore, thereby tuning the reactivity of the resultant biosensor.

The team used the biosensors for minimally invasive, sensitive, and selective imaging of hydrogen sulfide and peroxynitrite amidst other reactive chemical species in a complex cellular milieu. In particular, the sensors were used to detect physiological hydrogen sulfide in cancer cells and to detect peroxynitrite in macrophage immune cells and primary microglial cells. The project thus has resulted in a general strategy for probing redox-active small signaling molecules in living cells and subcellular locations.

The results of this project have been disseminated in a number of publications. Some of the results were published in top journals in the field, such as the Journal of the American Chemical Society and Nature Chemical Biology. Research tools developed by this project have been deposited to Addgene and sent to more than 100 laboratories to accelerate their studies.

This project has also facilitated curriculum development. In particular, a new lab was designed for the upper-division undergraduate course, Instrument Methods, at the University of California Riverside. In this new lab, students used capillary electrophoresis to separate mixtures of fluorescent proteins, and further investigate photophysical properties of individual proteins. 

The project also promoted an interdisciplinary training of a competitive STEM workforce. During the duration of this project, it supported the training of 9 graduate students (6 of them have received PhD degrees), ~ 10 undergraduate students, and ~ 11 high school students through laboratory research. This project brought them research experience in a unique area at the chemistry-biology interface. The trained students included persons from underrepresented groups and/or disadvantageous backgrounds.
